Award.AwardTitle: Multi-ion Dynamics of the Slow Solar Wind in Coronal Streamers
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Principal Investigator (PI) will perform a computational study of the formation and acceleration of the multi-ion solar wind in coronal streamers. He is motivated by the fact that previous MHD studies that have attempted to describe the solar wind plasma as a single fluid did not reproduce the observed properties of solar wind ions. In this effort, the PI will investigate the solar wind's multi-ion dynamics and compositional variations by developing comprehensive multidimensional and multi-fluid models of coronal streamers that incorporate heavy ions along with protons and electrons as separate but coupled fluids. He will study the effects of preferential heavy-ion heating and ion temperature anisotropies by including empirical heating terms, as well as wave heating and acceleration terms, in his new models. The PI will perform detailed comparisons between his models and available spectroscopic observations by calculating the ultraviolet (UV) emissivity expected from his multi-fluid model output. The computation of coronal emission based on the PI's models will allow him to estimate the expected intensity of UV spectral lines that will be detected using future coronagraphic instruments. This research will lead to a better understanding of the slow solar wind's composition and structure, as well as of the acceleration and heating processes that affect its plasma components.

This project will promote research and education by involving a graduate student who belongs to an underrepresented minority group, as well as by training a postdoctoral scholar. The numerical codes developed in this project will strengthen the nation's computational infrastructure by providing massively parallel multi-fluid models for use by other researchers. The PI's multidimensional, multi-fluid numerical modeling codes will be made available to the broader scientific community for ongoing solar wind research, as well as for other applications where multi-ion plasmas are present, such as in laboratory and astrophysical plasmas.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Sun's outer atmosphere (called solar corona) consistis of very hot gas of charged particles (called plasma) trapped in the solar magnetic field. These particles are primaraly electrons and protons, with smaller amounts of other ionized elements such as Helium and Oxygen. These particles eventually escape the Sun when the magnetic fields opens up into the interplanetary space. The plasma is gradually accelerated to very high speed of several hundered kilometers per second forming the so-called solar wind. However, the acceleration mechanism is not fully understood. The solar wind impacts the Earth and other planets, and affects the conditions in space (i.e., Space Weather) where satellites and astronauts operate. Therefore, it is important to understand the source and the variability of the solar wind. From satellite measurements we know that there are two types of solar wind: fast and steady, and slow and variable. The slow solar wind was associated with magnetic structures surrounding the sun called streamers. The goal of this study was to improved the understanding of the formation of the slow solar wind in these magnetic streamers that are the likely sources of the wind. Various minor ions were included in the newly developed model, in addition to electrons and protons for the first time, and the modeled properties of these minor ions, such as temperature density and speed, were compared to what is known from satellite observations. The agreement between the model and the observation provides information on the heating and the acceleration process of the solar wind. The understanding of the dynamics of the minor ions is important since they trace the sources of the solar wind and provide important information on the details of the acceleration mechanism. The study achieved significant progress in the modeling of the slow solar wind sources with more complex and detailed computational model than previoulsy. The new model includes important physical effects that were not previously considered. Thanks to the progress made, we are now able to predict how the coronal streamers would look in Ultraviolet images taken from space, and better understand the slow solar wind formation.
